titlepage.titleproper:
Finding aid for
Mary P. Sinclair papers, 1967-1999
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Michigan Historical Collections Staff

did.abstract: Lecturer, writer, and consultant on energy and environmental subjects, most notably the uses and hazards of nuclear energy. Correspondence; her statements, articles, and letters to newspaper editors; reference files; conference and consultation materials; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Mary Sinclair (donor no. 5569) beginning in 1981. Periodic additions have been received.

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Mary Sinclair donated her copyright to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Mary P. Sinclair papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Mary P. Sinclair was born September 23, 1918, in Chisholm, Minnesota. In 1940, she graduated from the College of St. Catherine (St. Paul, MN), majoring in chemistry and English. During the 1950s, she worked at the Library of Congress. There she first became interested in the problems of nuclear energy as a result of her work with classified material from the Atomic Energy Commission.

After moving to her husband's hometown of Midland, Michigan, Sinclair worked as a librarian and technical writer for the Dow Chemical Corporation until retiring to devote her time to raising her children. Her concern about nuclear energy continued, however, and in 1967, when Consumers Power announced plans to construct a nuclear plant in Midland, Sinclair began publicly questioning the move and writing critical letters to the Midland Daily News.

Despite the hostile reactions of other Midland residents, Sinclair escalated her fight against the nuclear plant in 1969, forming the Saginaw Valley Nuclear Study Group, which intervened as a party to the Atomic Energy Commission hearings on the plant. In 1972, she helped to organize National Intervenors, a coalition of anti-nuclear groups designed to intervene in hearings on nuclear safety. Sinclair earned an M.S. in environmental communications from the University of Michigan in 1973. From 1974 to 1978, she held the position of lecturer at the University of Michigan.

Sinclair has participated in numerous conferences on nuclear and environmental issues sponsored by such organizations as the Great Lakes Basin Commission, the Federal Energy Administration, and the United Auto Workers. She has been a member of the National Energy Policy Committee of the Sierra Club, which she represented at the World Energy Conference in Detroit in 1974. In 1978, Sinclair organized the Great Lakes Energy Alliance.

Sinclair's seventeen-year fight against the Consumers Power nuclear plant ended when Consumers Power canceled the plant in 1984. Shortly thereafter, she began working to end Michigan's involvement in the Midwest Compact, the result of the Radioactive Waste Policy Act of 1980 and its 1985 amendment which named Michigan as a dumping ground for low-level radioactive waste. In March 1988, Sinclair helped organize Don't Waste Michigan, a group dedicated to this issue. Michigan eventually withdrew from the Compact.

Sinclair earned her Ph.D. from the University of Michigan School of Natural Resources in 1991. Since receiving her Ph.D., Sinclair has actively opposed dry cask storage of high-level radioactive waste, especially near the Lake Michigan shore. She was also involved in considering issues relating to the clean-up of nuclear waste following the closing of Big Rock Nuclear Plant in 1997.

scopecontent.p: The Mary Sinclair collection provides detailed documentation of one woman's grassroots battle against nuclear power plants in Michigan. The collection, which was received in multiple accessions, has been arranged into the following series: Biographical and honors; Correspondence; Writings and speeches; People file; Early files; Citizen groups; Great Lakes Energy Alliance; University of Michigan; Government agencies; Midland Plant; Palisades Plant; Industries; Radiation; Alternatives to nuclear fission; Mass media; Topical files; Other cases; and Audio-visual material. The files contain both original and collected materials on topics related to her anti-nuclear activities.

The Biographical and Honors series (0.5 lin. ft.) contains documents relating to profiles of Sinclair which have appeared on 60 Minutes, and in the Wall Street Journal and Ms. Magazine, as well as scholarly papers written by individuals researching Sinclair's role in the environmental movement. Producer Chris Weicher's research files pertaining to the 60 Minutes program document events which Sinclair herself judged most important for her biography. This series also includes transcripts of interviews with Sinclair and several versions of her resumes.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence (3.5 lin. ft.) is arranged into two subseries, first by date, and second by subject/correspondent. Sinclair's files contain not only incoming letters, but also copies of her replies. Correspondents include other citizen activists such as Christa-Maria, Kay Drey, Gerald and Martha Drake, Billie Garde, and Helen LeTarte. Researchers seeking information about these individuals should consult files in the "People File" series as well.

Nearly one box of this material is related to Sinclair's 1992-1994 correspondence with Fawn Shillinglaw, an anti-nuclear activist who resided in Appleton, Wisconsin and shared her research on dry cask storage of nuclear waste with Sinclair. This material supported the Kelley v. Selin lawsuit. Other files document correspondence with politicians and industry officials.

odd.p: (See also Big Rock files)

scopecontent.p: The Writing and Speeches series (1.8 lin. ft.) contains Sinclair's articles, letters to the editor, statements before legislative bodies, and speeches, as well as copies of unpublished sources and interview transcripts her work relies upon. In the original accession (Box 2), her works are individually foldered and arranged by date. Sinclair's works in the later accessions (Boxes 21 and 22) are gathered together in chronological files, except for those works which have additional supporting documentation, which are separately foldered. There is significant chronological overlap between the two accessions.

scopecontent.p: The People File (1.2 lin. ft.) series contains a variety of materials, such as clippings, speeches and articles by and concerning the subject, correspondence to and from the subject, and legal pleadings and documents associated with that person. . The material in this series derives entirely from the first accession. In the later accessions (beginning after Box 19), material regarding individuals may be located in the Correspondence or Topical files series.

(U. of M. Professor of Physics)

did.unittitle: Ryan, William A., Speaker of Mich. House 1974

scopecontent.p: The Early Files series (1.5 lin. ft.) contains files from the beginning of Sinclair's career as an activist. Correspondence, articles, legal papers, and speeches are gathered by topic and arranged alphabetically.

The Citizen Groups series (5.2 lin. ft.) documents the interlocking network of citizen environmental groups. By gathering and exchanging information, validating and celebrating each other's work, and providing templates and roadmaps for grassroots organizations addressing similar problems, these groups cooperated in advancing their environmental agenda. Materials included in these files include newsletters, correspondence, flyers, educational materials, and bibliographies. Don't Waste Michigan, the Saginaw Valley Nuclear Study Group, and the Sierra Club National Energy Committee were organizations through which Sinclair funneled her activism. The materials for the Great Lakes Energy Alliance are contained in a separate series, which follows.

When Sinclair's work was funded by a grantmaker (such as the Sierra Club Foundation) she provided her benefactor with periodic summaries of how her work was progressing. These letters are a valuable resource because they provide a substantially contemporaneous account of Sinclair's successes, failures, and future plans.

scopecontent.p: The Great Lakes Energy Alliance files (1.0 lin. ft.) contain organizational records, such as membership lists, publicity and minutes and topical files relating to the group's involvement in specific events, such as the licensing hearings for the Fermi II nuclear plant. The periodic update reports that Sinclair sent to her grant funders at the CS Fund and the Children's fund (including repeated correspondence with Maryanne Mott) give a clear and contemporaneous picture of Sinclair's goals and objectives.

did.unittitle: Fermi II (Lawsuit and petition to intervene)
Michigan Coalition on Utilities and Energy

odd.p: (Jennifer E. Puntenney)

scopecontent.p: Materials in the University of Michigan series (1.4 lin. ft.) relate to Sinclair's work as a graduate student and lecturer. She received her MS in environmental communications in 1973 and a PhD at the School of Natural Resources in 1991. Syllabi, class work and correspondence with her professors may be found here. Her theses, however, are located in the Writing and Speeches Series. She held the position of lecturer from 1974 to 1978. Lecture materials and papers from conferences she attended in relation to this role are found in this series.

did.unittitle: Bryant, Bunyan "Social Change: Energy and Land Ethics" 1979

Sandman, Peter, "Mass Media and the Environment," 1973
Statement of intent for doctoral program

scopecontent.p: The Government Agencies files (1.6 lin. ft.) represent Sinclair's work with governmental regulators. The materials include government reports, correspondence, articles and legal pleadings. They are arranged into subseries for Federal, Regional, State and Local governmental bodies, and one for Legislation. This series contains only documents from the first accession. For the later time period, a researcher should look to the Topical Files series to locate information about government agencies.

scopecontent.p: The Midland Plant, NRC hearings series (6.4 lin. ft.) documents the ongoing battle of Sinclair and her compatriots against unsafe conditions at the Midland Nuclear Power Plant. The materials in the first accession (boxes 13-16) are presented as they were received, and are in chronological order. Materials from several simultaneous legal actions, correspondence and research materials are mixed together in these files. They comprise the "Chronological" subseries.

The later accession for this series (boxes 30-34) contains substantial chronological overlap and probable duplication with the first accession, but the materials are separated according to genre. The "General" subseries includes correspondence, research, clippings and reports and is arranged alphabetically. The "Pleadings and Orders" subseries and the "Transcripts" subseries are arranged chronologically. The transcripts contained in this last series are voluminous documents which represent verbatim accounts of evidentiary hearings.

scopecontent.p: The Palisades Plant, NRC hearings series contains legal documents relating to the permit hearings for the Palisades Nuclear Power Plant, arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: The Industries series contains files pertaining to Sinclair's interaction with industry, (particularly Dow Chemical Co. and Consumers Power Co.) Files are arranged alphabetically by company and hold company publications, newsletters and correspondence. This series contains material from the original accession only (pre-1981). Researchers interested in specific corporations should consult the Topical Files series in the later accession (boxes 22-27) under headings for those companies.

The Radiation series holds Sinclair's research about the effects of radiation. It consists largely of articles she collected on the topic, and very little work from her own hand. It is arranged alphabetically by topic.

Like the Radiation series, the Alternatives to nuclear fission series contains research documents on the topic of nuclear fission. There are, however, two substantial correspondence files which document Sinclair's 1971 campaign to make political leaders aware of alternative energy technologies. The files are arranged alphabetically by topic.

The Mass Media Files (0.5 lin. ft.)are arranged alphabetically and contain documentation of Sinclair's attention to the coverage her projects were garnering in the media. Materials include correspondence with reporters, manuscript scripts and articles written by and about Sinclair, and some clippings, particularly in the Bay City Times folder.

The Topical Files series (6.0 lin. ft.) contains files documenting Sinclair's work on various environmental issues and is arranged alphabetically, by topic. The later accession (Boxes 22-27), following Sinclair's own original arrangement of the folders, gathers together in this series topics which were separated into separate series in the original accession, such as "People file," "Government Agencies," "Industries," "Radiation," "Alternatives to nuclear fission," and "Mass media." It includes significant subseries on Dow Chemical Company, (including the Midland/Dow Citizens Advisory Panel), and Press (including comprehensive press coverage of the Midland controversies in the Midland Daily News and Ann Arbor News.)

scopecontent.p: The Other Cases series (1.2 lin. ft.) contains documents related to legal proceedings other than the NRC licensing hearings for the Midland and Palisades plants. Sinclair's participation in disputes before the Michigan Public Service Commission, (which regulates utilities and electricity rates) is documented here. This series also contains papers related to Kelley v. Selin (high level nuclear waste storage at the Palisades plant), the Aeschliman case (sometimes called the "Table S.3 Case"), and the licensing of the Fermi II plant. All of these files are from the later accessions.

scopecontent.p: The audio-visual materials series (1.8 lin. ft.) contains videotapes, sound recordings (cassette and reel-to-reel), photographs, slides, anti-nuke slogan buttons, and rally flyers.
